section.title: Gist of Vertical and Horizontal Translations

paragraphs.p: To transform a function means to change it either its input or its output. If the change is only in position (the graph looks the same, but in a different location) the change is called a translation.
In this chapter we learn how to translate a graph or a table of values. This will involve adding or subtracting values to the input and/or the output of a function's formula.
It will be important for us to distinguish between the input and the output of a function. For instance, we must understand that the function f(x) = x^2 - 5x has an input x and an output f(x).
If the input is decreased by 3, then the output would be f(x−3). If the output is increased by 4, it would become f(x) + 4.
If you evaluate a function by using x, then the output will have x’s in it. But if you substitute x–3 into the function, then the output will have (x-3)’s in it.

statement.p: For the function f(x) = x^2 - 5x, simplify the following:

paragraphs.p: One natural question to ask is How does changing the input alter the graph of f(x)? It turns out that subtracting 3 from the input would move the graph of f to the right by 3 units, and adding 4 to the output would move the graph to the left by 1 unit. This is called a horizontal translation (or horizontal shift).
In short: Adding a number to the input will shift the graph to the left. Subtracting a number from the input will shift the graph to the right.
In fact, whenever you do anything to the input of a function, the result is some kind of horizontal change to the graph.

solution.p: Adding a negative number to the input will move a graph to the right.
Adding a positive number to the input will move a graph to the left.

paragraphs.p: On the other hand, if you make changes to the output of the function, it will affect the graph vertically. In this section, we see that adding or subtracting from the output will produce a vertical translation of the graph up or down.
In short: Adding a number to the ouput will shift the graph up. Subtracting a number from the output will shift the graph down.

solution.p: After a function has been evaluated, such as f(x), this output represents the y-value of a point. So, adding a number to this output would just add to the y-value, causing the points to be higher or lower on the graph.

paragraphs.title: Translations in context
paragraphs.p: Of course, translations should do more for us than just provide a quick way to move graphs around. If a function describes something about a real object or situation, then knowing about changes to that object should help us alter the function to account for those changes.
